questions.question_text:
The deliverables of a project have been completed. However, the stakeholders did not approve the deliverables, because they did not cover the needs of the business.
Which actions should the project manager have taken to avoid this situation?

choices.A: Plan the delivery of a minimum viable feature in 2 weeks to enable early showcasing of business value.
choices.D: Add the new feature to the list for the next release and continue working on the current release.
choices.B: Stop the current release work for 4 weeks in order to work and deliver the new feature completely.
choices.C: Create a special release 4 weeks after the current release to deliver the new feature in its entirety.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Why A is Correct:
✅ 1. Delivering Value Incrementally (PMBOK Principle 2: Deliver Value)

A Minimum Viable Feature (MVF) allows for early showcasing of business value without delaying the entire functionality.
Even though the back end (Company B) takes longer, a front-end prototype or partial functionality can still provide insights and marketing validation.

Option A makes the most sense. Delivering a minimum viable feature in 2 weeks lets the marketing department showcase some business value early on. This approach provides a compromise, giving a sneak peek while buying time for Company B to finish their part without derailing the current workflow.
A. Plan the delivery of a minimum viable feature in 2 weeks to enable early showcasing of business value.
